docs.lead_paragraph: The Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation is seeking a shake-up of Citigroup's top management, including replacing the chief executive, Vikram S. Pandit, The Wall Street Journal reported, citing people familiar with the matter.

headline.main: F.D.I.C. Said to Eye Shake-Up at Citigroup

docs.abstract: The F.D.I.C. is said to be seeking a shake-up of Citigroup's top management, including replacing Chief Executive Vikram Pandit, The Wall Street Journal reported.
docs.snippet: The F.D.I.C. is said to be seeking a shake-up of Citigroup's top management, including replacing Chief Executive Vikram Pandit, The Wall Street Journal reported.

docs.lead_paragraph: Uwe E. Reinhardt is an economics professor at Princeton.

headline.main: Reader Response: How Much Do We Spend on Health Care?

docs.abstract: An economist explains how much Americans pay for health care, and what the long-term projections look like.
docs.snippet: An economist explains how much Americans pay for health care, and what the long-term projections look like.

docs.lead_paragraph: Health reform will fail without serious cost control, which will require a fundamental change in the way the insurance industry behaves.

docs.lead_paragraph: Despite the Republicans’ concerns, Democratic leaders expressed confidence that they could come together on a bill producing near-universal coverage.

docs.lead_paragraph: Concerns over bird flu helped prepare the United States for the current swine flu outbreak, but officials cautioned that there were still gaps in planning.

docs.lead_paragraph: Updated, June 5, 11:40 a.m. | Karen Davenport, director of health policy at the Center for American Progress, offers a view on the politics of mandatory health coverage.
docs.abstract: Is requiring every American to have medical insurance the best way to begin health care reform?
docs.snippet: Is requiring every American to have medical insurance the best way to begin health care reform?

docs.lead_paragraph: One of the most highly sensitive issues in the Senate is the health condition of Senator Edward M. Kennedy, of Massachusetts, the well-loved liberal lion and chairman of the Health, Education, Labor and Pensions Committee, who continues to be treated for brain cancer at a time when he hoped to be leading the effort to pass comprehensive health care legislation.

headline.main: Kennedy's Absence Felt by Lawmakers on Health Care Bill

docs.abstract: With the pace of the legislative debate accelerating rapidly this week, Democrats finally designated Senator Edward M. Kennedy's close friend, Senator Christopher J. Dodd to take the lead on the health committee.
docs.snippet: With the pace of the legislative debate accelerating rapidly this week, Democrats finally designated Senator Edward M. Kennedy's close friend, Senator Christopher J. Dodd to take the lead on the health committee.

docs.lead_paragraph: Nearly two out of three bankruptcies stem from medical bills, and even people with health insurance face financial disaster if they experience a serious illness, a new study shows.
docs.abstract: Even patients with health insurance are forced to declare bankruptcy after a serious illness.
docs.snippet: Even patients with health insurance are forced to declare bankruptcy after a serious illness.

docs.lead_paragraph: If the Senate Republican leader, Mitch McConnell of Kentucky, has his way, two faces of the debate over American health care reform will be Shona Holmes of Ontario, Canada, and Bruce Hardy, of Ruislip, England.

headline.main: A Senator Offers Two Faces in Health Care Debate

docs.abstract: The Republican minority leader has taken his campaign against a public health insurance plan onto the floor of the Senate, complete with anecdotes about patients -- albeit missing a few details along the paths of their care.
docs.snippet: The Republican minority leader has taken his campaign against a public health insurance plan onto the floor of the Senate, complete with anecdotes about patients -- albeit missing a few details along the paths of their care.

docs.lead_paragraph: The Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation indefinitely postponed a central element of the Obama administration's bank rescue plan Wednesday, acknowledging that it could not persuade enough banks to sell off their bad assets, The New York Times's Edmund L. Andrews reported.

headline.main: Banks Would Rather Keep Their Bad Loans, for Now

docs.abstract: The F.D.I.C. postponed a central piece of the U.S. bank rescue plan indefinitely, acknowledging that it could not persuade enough banks to sell off their bad assets.
docs.snippet: The F.D.I.C. postponed a central piece of the U.S. bank rescue plan indefinitely, acknowledging that it could not persuade enough banks to sell off their bad assets.
